Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: STUDIES OF ANION-RECEPTOR AND CH-ANION BINDING USING TRIAZOLOPHANES
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program supports Professor Amar Flood of Indiana University for the synthesis and characterization of modular anion-binding receptors, called triazolophanes. Surprisingly, these triazolophanes incorporate only weak CH hydrogen bond donors. Therefore, the structural and electronic parameters that enforce strong anion affinities in these receptors will be determined by thermodynamic analyses. As a consequence of these investigations, the strengths of the two types of CH donors will be addressed. The effects of electronics, size and shape, flexibility, charge, axial ligation and dimerization will be evaluated. Secondly, template-directed approaches will be developed to effect more efficient syntheses of the triazolophanes by conducting kinetics studies in a step-wise manner on the individual reaction steps involved in the overall one-pot preparation. The proposed research will answer questions about how triazolophanes bind anions, how strong the C-H H-bonding interactions are, and about the templating effect of anions in macrocyclization.

With the support of the Organic Dynamics Program in the Chemistry Division, Dr. Flood is developing inquiry-based learning modules using nanoscience and nanotechnology as a hook for non-science majors at local high schools and at the undergraduate level in order to engage students with science. The PI wants to introduce high school students to real scientific inquiry in the lecture hall versus canned discourse in which individuals can choose their particular level of involvement. He is going to use the chemical technology and the nanoscience involved in producing the iPod to attract students. For the younger people who are interested in playing video games, the PI is going to involve game theory in education. To help with this project, he is collaborating with the Indiana University College of Education to use virtual worlds (Quest Atlantis) and gaming strategies to attract the younger students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: STUDIES OF ANION-RECEPTOR AND CH-ANION BINDING USING TRIAZOLOPHANES 

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

Anions have many roles across a range of chemical and biological; a situation that motivates investigations into ways to monitor and regulate them. These roles include the beneficial use of fertilizer (anionic nitrates and phosphates) to help grow the crops to feed the people of the planet. But those same fertilizers run-off into streams and rivers leading to algal blooms, dead waterways and are thus environmental hazards. Underpinning each of these roles is the need to understand how to capture anions using synthetic receptors. In this NSF funded program, we designed, synthesized and investigated a range of novel receptors for anions. Their novelty lies in the first use of a wholly new class of hydrogen bond based on carbon donors that originate from molecular building blocks, called triazoles. The triazoles are easy to install as well as functioning to stabilize anions. Thus, we provided the first look at how such CH hydrogen bonds, traditionally considered too weak, could be used to stabilize anions.

We were the first to outline the conditions under which CH hydrogen bonding can be strong enough to stabilize anions by using donut-shaped macrocycles, called triazolophanes. We showed that the CH hydrogen bonds work best when many of them are present, when they are all held rigidly in position and when they are all pointing into the center of a macrocycle. In order to establish these rules by which CH hydrogen bonds engage with anions, we had to develop and make use of detailed quantitative analyses of the ways and strengths with which anions bind to triazole-based receptors. In so doing, we discovered the way in which the anion’s counter-cation participates in anion recognition. We also made use of the quantitative studies to show that the cyanide anion can be bound by the CH hydrogen bonded array inside the macrocycle and that it rotates in plane to behave exactly the same as the chloride anion. Finally, we explained the greater strength of triazolophanes when compared to calix[4]pyrroles arises from their rigidity even though they have weaker CH hydrogen bonds.

All told, we have supported the transformative idea that CH?donors can be just as reliable as NH hydrogen bond donors. Furthermore, we have generalized the concept. We did this by creating of a totally new class of macrocycle, called cyanostars, which only use CH hydrogen bond donors. We showed the phenomenal outcome that the cyanostar macrocycle can be easily made in very high yields, in pot one and on the multi-gram scale. In vindication of everything this project has taught us, we showed strong binding to over 12 anions. Furthermore, we discovered that the binding for large anions, like perchlorate, was over 1 billion times larger than all others reports. This idea is transforming our classification of “weak anions”. We also used this preference for larger anions to make the first ring-on-axle rotaxane that uses a phosphate anion as its central templating agent.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

The project has helped with the training of graduate and undergraduate students in the PI's laboratory. Training of undergraduate students also at Douglas Vander Griend's Calvin College has also resulted.

In total, 7 graduate and 2 undergraduate students have been trained. 1 graduate student works for 3M; 3 undergraduates attend graduate school (UCSD, UW-Madison, Oxford) of which the latter is an African American woman who received a Rhodes Scholarship.
